Award.AwardTitle: R/V Clifford A. Barnes Ship Operations 2012-2016
Award.AbstractNarration: This award is in direct support of Research Vessel Clifford A. Barnes, and is funded in order to conduct NSF peer-reviewed oceanographic research in Calendar Year 2012. R/V Clifford A. Barnes is owned by the National Science Foundation and operated by the University of Washington. The ship works primarily in the sheltered waters of Western Washington, British Columbia, including Puget Sound and Lake Washington. In 2012, R/V Clifford A. Barnes plans to operate 124 days, of which 89 days will be in direct support of NSF research. This is a five-year cooperative agreement, and funding for the years 2013-2016 will be re-negotiated and evaluated based on the number of days at sea in support of peer-reviewed sea-going NSF-funded research. R/V Clifford A. Barnes is operated as a member of the University National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS). The University of Washington remains committed to managing this facility in a safe, cost-effective, and environmentally responsible manner.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for NSF Grant 1215832 - R/V Clifford A. Barnes Ship Operations 2012-2017 

Note: Grant extended by NSF to cover 2018 in addition to original 5-year period

R/V Clifford A. Barnes, a 65-foot Local Class research vessel owned by the National Science Foundation and operated by the University of Washington as part of the University National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) fleet, has operated throughout Puget Sound, around and within the fjords of Vancouver Island, and on Lake Washington during the seven years covered by this grant to further man?s understanding of our oceans.  While operating at an average of 84.5 days per year, R/V Barnes conducted 114 oceanographic research cruises that were funded by the National Science Foundation, the Office of Naval Research, NOAA, and the University of Washington (UW).  In doing so, all disciplines of oceanography and many other elements of science have been served including biological, chemical and physical oceanography plus marine geology and geophysics.  Numerous research papers, vast quantities of data, informative websites and blogs, and a variety of cruise reports document the far-ranging extent of the successful research conducted onboard R/V Barnes during this period and are available through a variety of public sources.  

In addition, R/V Barnes conducted numerous academic cruises taking UW School of Oceanography students to sea.  R/V Barnes averaged 10 days/year underway directly in support of UW academic programs.  In addition, students participated in many of the other science cruises onboard R/V Barnes.  The seagoing academic program onboard the Barnes, in direct support to the UW School of Oceanography, enables students to be initiated into the challenging world of ship-based sampling and data collection, further maturing their understanding of the oceanographic sciences. The Barnes served as an intimate seagoing platform and oceanographic research environment where students can work side-by-side with instructors in completing hands-on data collection, sampling and specimen recovery that provided a fundamental foundation for future oceanographers to grow their skills.  This comprehensive sea-going program, complimented by the rigorous program of classes and projects, provided a robust foundation for UW Oceanography students to develop into world-class oceanographers.

Throughout this grant period R/V Clifford A. Barnes underwent regular comprehensive NSF inspections that helped to ensure the vessel, crew, and ship management meet all regulatory requirements and continued to operate in safest manner possible while incorporating maritime industry best practices.   These inspections helped to ensure proper maintenance was conducted, established oceanographic research safety practices were followed, and the ship was upgraded regularly to meet the emerging needs of the scientific community. R/V Barnes was drydocked regularly to enable proper maintenance took place.

The now 52-year old R/V Clifford A. Barnes was retired in early 2018 as the University of Washington purchased the former R/V AORA to provide a newer, more capable Local Class research vessel to replace the Barnes.  During its 35-year career as an NSF-owned, UW-operated oceanographic research vessel R/V Clifford A. Barnes conducted 1,083 oceanographic research cruises.  The now-R/V Rachel Carson began oceanographic science and academic cruises in April 2018.  R/V Barnes will be sold and any funds realized from the sale will be invested in scientific upgrades to R/V Carson in accordance with NSF Guidance. 

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2018
Modified by: Doug G Russell
